Sir Alex Ferguson intended to give Darren his debut as a 16-year-old against Aston Villa in May 2000 yet Fletcher senior's first two years at United were stunted by injury.

Jack was virtuoso in the FA Youth Cup win against Derby County at Old Trafford last month and his raking half-volleyed pass made it possible for Ethan Williams to notch the only goal. Fletcher's technique made Ben Thornley, the fleet-footed Class of '92 winger on co-commentary for MUTV in the press box, purr before it had even reached Ethan Wheatley.
The memory is already soured. Swindon shocked United in the fourth round on Tuesday night with a 2-0 win at the County Ground.

Jack got a ticking off from the referee for backchat. One of his corners failed to beat the first man and the second seconds later went over everyone. He ended the game bickering with an opponent. Fletcher's father excelled at playing the opponent rather than the occasion and Jack will have to learn from a galling evening in Wiltshire.

United are reluctant to elaborate on the Fletcher twins' development. A source said staff want to "keep it as low-key as possible", perhaps conscious of overhyping two lads who would be in Year 12 if still at school, or fuelling any accusations of nepotism. An early ejection from the Youth Cup vindicates the reticence.

Tyler posed for his intimate unveiling photo, clutching a shirt with 'Fletcher 6', in the Old Trafford boardroom in August. In the background, there was a framed monochrome photograph of Ryan Giggs triumphantly hoisting the European Cup on the Manchester Airport tarmac in 2008. Peer closer and Darren is visible in the background on the passenger boarding steps.
On the same day, Jack stood on the Old Trafford pitch and brandished his own shirt. That was one way to tell which is which.

headline: Scoring 100 goals a season and sharing a Roy Keane trait - Dan Gore's United journey
body: Dan Gore couldn't help but smile throughout his post-match interview after making his Manchester United debut.

Gore made his senior bow against Crystal Palace in the Carabao Cup and he fought an excitable grin as he answered questions. The game also coincided with his 19th birthday and his family were present to enjoy the occasion, which Gore described as 'truly special' after growing up supporting the club.

“It tops the list of birthdays," Gore said while trying to keep his composure. "I don’t think words can describe that feeling, seeing the fans, it is everything you’ve dreamed of, coming true. It means everything."
Gore became the 247th player to make his debut from the academy that night, reward for making excellent progress and convincing Erik ten Hag he was ready.
He trained with the first-team for 12 weeks before his debut and is known to 'train every day like his life depends on it', something which his former coaches at Burnley loved about him.

Although Gore is a Salford-lad and he idolised Wayne Rooney and Cristiano Ronaldo when he was a kid, he only joined United in 2018, having previously been at Burnley where he played as a forward, not a midfielder.

"Those types seemed to have that little bit more extra bite than your local kids. He was a forward when he came to us and he’d either play wide left or right or as the number nine and he was the top scorer through his age groups.

"He was quick and very strong for his size. He always had aggression and he was one of the kids who played on the edge, in terms of maybe making the odd bad challenge, but it was interesting because he was always respectful.

"He had great finishing ability in his younger years, one-on-one, going past people and he always had that bit where he was a winner. If he was getting beat, there was nobody on the pitch who hated it more and you could see that fire in him. Dan had that brilliant, real f****** horrible side to him, but he'd always be respectful with coaches and it wasn't a surprise when I saw him three months ago and he ran over and gave me a hug when I hadn’t seen him for years."

Gore joined United at 13 and the decision was made to drop him deeper into midfield. "My last day working for Burnley, I had to deliver his review to his dad," Craig said when asked about his position change.

"Although he was a great striker, I didn’t think he scored poachers goals, like your Harry Kane or Ole Gunnar Solskjaer. He scored amazing goals and he was off the charts, but I thought he could be a better instinctive finisher.

"I remember his dad saying thank you because all he'd had for a couple of years was people telling him how good he was and nobody had said things to work on. He was prolific and he’d beat a few men and fire one into the top corner, but if someone wrapped a ball across the 18-yard box at speed, he probably didn’t have that instinctive finish in him every time.

"But he worked on it religiously. He always worked on stuff and he was in training early, even as a kid. I never pictured him as a midfielder because although his awareness was decent, it's different playing in that role. He’s developed his awareness now and when I see him driving the ball in midfield, it’s similar to how he played back then."
Mike Hargreaves, who considers Gore as the best young player he's encountered, is another former Burnley coach who worked with the youngster and he spoke to the MEN about that period.

"I worked with Danny at Burnley from Under-9s to Under-12s and I took that age group all the way through, so I worked with him for quite a while, and outside of Burnley with my own coaching," Hargreaves said.

"Some of the things I’ve seen him do for United, he’s been doing since back then. He’s dropped deeper now, but when he played up front for Burnley he'd score over 100 goals each season and I’m not even exaggerating.

"There was a game at Blackburn once when we built possession well, Dan picked the ball up inside his own half and he just started running past people and he ended up finishing it off, which was unbelievable. There was another time when he faced someone up, stopped the ball dead and did the Yannick Bolaise showboating thing when he bent down and flicked the grass, so he had a little bit of cheekiness about him.

"He was a matchwinner and they were a really good group. I always thought It was just a matter of time before United would come in for him and I always expected that. I can’t think of many times he didn't have a good day."

Hargreaves continued: "His real stand-out qualities were he was hard-working, aggressive, he put himself about and he was a really exciting dribbler. He was fantastic with the ball and capable of sprinting repeatedly. His speed endurance was phenomenal, even at those ages. His attitude was great and he was demanding of his teammates and the standards of the session.

"Towards the end of Under-11s, we had a tournament on Blackpool’s pitch and it was a full-day affair. We played United in the final of that and Danny scored. They were just completely top draw that day as a group.

"I remember building up to that tournament for a few weeks and reiterating what we were building up to and you’d see a change in him, almost like a switch being flicked and a refocus. You could see he wanted to win."
The burning desire to improve and win has seen Gore become a member of the first-team squad with Ten Hag in charge and he's worn the captain's armband when playing in academy matches this season.

"He’s captain material I'd say," Craig added. "Almost like your old-school Roy Keane type with hard challenges, but he’s got unbelievable quality on the ball because he was a forward in the past as well.

"In that Under-21 group at United, there have been the likes of Shola Shoretire and Isak Hasen-Aaroen but it seems like there's been something missing in them, which doesn’t seem to be the case with Dan. If you leave him in an environment long enough he thrives and I think it's fair to say that Dan wasn’t a Burnley type of player, in the sense that he was probably beyond Burnley in terms of his ability.

"He would have played for Burnley’s first-team if he was still there and Sean Dyche would have been all over him, but there was always an acceptance of Dan was Salford, Man United and there were murmurings going on in the background. Kids get poached in academies all the time, but I think Burnley got looked after with the deal when he did go over. And I think he was given certain guarantees because United knew the talent they were getting."

Gore was part of the FA Youth Cup winning side in 2022 and although Alejandro Garnacho was the poster boy of that campaign, his partnership with Kobbie Mainoo in midfield was instrumental in the success. More than 60,000 supporters watched the final at Old Trafford and Gore kissed the badge when the full time whistle went. It wasn't a surprise for a boy who used to wear a red thermal vest under his Burnley shirt.
"You can tell what Manchester United means to him when he plays," Craig said. "I went to the Youth Cup final and I just thought he was outstanding, doing the horrible side of the game really well.

"I thought out of possession, Dan was excellent, picking up second balls and showing all the stuff he's added to his game as a midfielder and you can see he's got a real understanding of the game now."

Hargreaves was also in the crowd and he briefly talked to Gore during the celebrations. "I saw him right at the end when they were doing the lap of honour because I was sitting near the front, so I went down and shouted.

"He said 'aaaah Mike!' and I congratulated him, so it was nice to have that moment and I did have to laugh because near the end of the Youth Cup final, he was tapping his head and telling people to focus.

"That’s stuck with me because it’s something I do myself. We had great times at Burnley and he was the star of the group. I’ve got a great relationship with him and his dad, who was always very grateful for us looking after him."

Gore has been on an upward trajectory since and Bruno Fernandes is understood to have been very welcoming to the youngster, taking a hands-on role in his integration into the first-team. Sources have also indicated Jonny Evans has been especially supportive and offered Gore plenty of advice since they started training together in mid-July, which the 19-year-old has appreciated.

"You’re around top players every day at United and you either adapt or die," Craig said. "Even if he ends up making 100 appearances for United in the Premier League or with another club, he'll get the most out of himself.
"Ten Hag has been known for developing youngsters at Ajax and he doesn’t put people in who aren’t good enough. I'm really proud of him and it's lovely when you bump into him, or get a text."

Hargreaves echoed those comments: "It’s been brilliant to see him progress and I’m a United fan myself, so I'm extremely pleased because it's more than he deserves. I genuinely think he embodies what a United player should be, bringing excitement, being hard-working and holding himself in the right way."

Gore recently shaved his head - going for a buzzcut style - and there was a large smile on his face when he revealed his new haircut to his amused teammates at Carrington. That wide grin doesn't seem to be going away anytime soon.

headline: Exclusive - United make decision on Amad's future
body: Manchester United are planning to keep Amad beyond the closure of the January transfer window.
United expect Facundo Pellistri to join Granada on loan and believe Amad has an important role to play in the squad.
Amad, 21, made his first United appearance in more than two years as a substitute in the 2-1 defeat to Nottingham Forest on January 30.
The Ivory Coast international missed the FA Cup third round win against Wigan Athletic through illness and he could return to the squad for the fourth round tie at Newport County next week.
United signed Amad for £19million rising to £37m from Atalanta on transfer deadline day in October 2020 and the winger has played 10 times for the club.
EXCLUSIVE: Brailsford meeting former United staff with 'brutal' changes planned

Amad spent the second half of the 2021-22 season on loan at Rangers and shone during a season-long loan at Sunderland last term. Amad scored 14 goals in 42 games for the Championship side as Sunderland reached the play-offs.
Pellistri was due to leave on loan in the summer but ended up remaining at United after Amad sustained a knee injury in the pre-season win against Arsenal in July.
Amad returned to training in early December and he performed creditably off the bench in the loss at Forest.

headline: How Man United should line up vs Brentford in Premier League fixture as Amorim can hand out debut
body: Manchester United play Brentford in the Premier League this afternoon.
United's focus is on winning the Europa League and Ruben Amorim's side secured an outstanding 3-0 victory against Athletic Bilbao ahead of the second leg at Old Trafford next week.
Amorim is expected to rotate his starting team against Brentford at the Gtech Stadium and he has confirmed Noussair Mazraoui will not play because he's at the "limit to get an injury."
This is how our writers think United should line up against Brentford...
United should play a completely different outfield team. There is no need to rotate the goalkeeper and Andre Onana has had a steady few weeks.

Matthijs de Ligt and Amad could do with more minutes as starters after their return from injury in midweek. The midfield is an issue as United do not have a designated holding midfielder and that might be a role Mason Mount has to temporarily adopt. He has not created much and often gets booked, so he should be able to adapt.
It is a logical day to give Chido Obi a full debut and Jaydan Kamason would be the natural pick in the absence of a senior right back/right winger.

United's commanding position from the unexpected events in Bilbao have given Amorim licence to pick a stronger team than might otherwise have been the case, but I don't see the need to risk it, especially with a final now coming into view. Eleven changes it is.

That means Bayindir gets a start in goal. In defence, Fredricson is back in, Shaw can start again on the left and it's a chance to get substantial minutes into De Ligt, with a view to him starting on Thursday night.
Mazraoui and Dorgu are certainties to be rested and that means Kamason can make his debut and it's another start for Amass. Mainoo can play in a deeper midfield role alongside debutant Kone.
Mount and Eriksen offer experience as the No. 10s and there is no need to risk Hojlund, so it's a first start for 17-year-old Obi.
This is the perfect opportunity to give Kamason his first-team debut. He's been brilliant for the U18s this season and deserves the chance to start against Brentford in the absence of Mazraoui.
It doesn't make much sense to rotate Onana, so he should retain his starting role in between the sticks, and Amad should make his first start since recovering from an ankle injury.
Mount has been limited to substitute appearances and should also start this afternoon.

Despite having one foot in the Europa League final, nothing can be taken for granted ahead of Thursday night's second leg at Old Trafford, meaning if I was Amorim, I would make wholesale changes in order to keep key players fresh and give them a breather so soon after the win in Bilbao.

Despite not covering himself in glory at Newcastle, Bayindir should come in to replace Onana. The back-three ahead of him ought to feature a first start since April 1 for De Ligt after he came on against Athletic.
Kamason has offered plenty of promise for the Under-18s this season and deserves a chance to show what he can do at right wing-back. Amass has already proven he is capable on the opposite flank.
Fellow youngster Obi also deserves his full debut at the tip of the attack after a handful of substitute appearances. Amad should also start if he his fitness levels allow him to.

headline: Manchester United predicted XI vs Brentford as Ruben Amorim set to hand out two full debuts
body: Manchester United travel to Brentford on Sunday afternoon as they turn their attention back towards the Premier League.
Ruben Amorim's side were excellent in midweek as they beat Spanish side Athletic Bilbao 3-0 away from home in the first leg of the Europa League semi-final.

United are just two games from winning some European silverware that would secure Champions League qualification next season, so a number of big players are expected to be rested for the trip to Brentford.
Amorim has hinted he will use the rest of the Premier League season to blood some youngsters and, with that in mind, there could be two full debuts handed out at the Gtech Community Stadium.
Andre Onana will start in goal, while Tyler Fredricson, who made his first United appearance in the defeat to Wolves last month, is expected to start in the back three.
Fredricson will be joined by Matthijs De Ligt, who made his comeback from injury off the bench in the win over Bilbao, and Luke Shaw who has impressed since returning from injury last month.
At right-wing-back, 18-year-old Jaydan Kamason, who has been on the bench for United's last three Europa League games, is expected to be handed his Unite debut.
Teenager Harry Amass is expected to continue his encouraging development at left-wing-back with Kobbie Mainoo and Christian Eriksen being handed an opportunity to impress in midfield.
Amad is expected to make his first start since February after recovering from an ankle injury and he is expected to be joined by Mason Mount in the second 'number 10' slot.

With Rasmus Hojlund shouldering all of the goalscoring burden in the absence of Joshua Zirkzee, he could be handed a rest up front with teenage striker Chido Obi possibly being handed his full debut after six appearances from the bench this season.
Manchester United predicted XI vs Brentford: Onana; Fredricson, De Ligt, Shaw; Kamason, Mainoo, Eriksen, Amass; Amad, Mount; Obi

headline: How to watch Brentford vs Man United - TV channel, live stream and kick-off time
body: Manchester United return to Premier League action this weekend with a trip to Brentford on Sunday afternoon.

Ruben Amorim's side eased past Athletic Bilbao in the Europa League on Thursday evening with a 3-0 win, putting them one step closer to the final on May 21. Europe's second-tier competition is the Reds' sole focus now with a place in next season's Champions League on offer to the winner.

But they will be looking to continue their momentum when they travel to west London. They face a Brentford team who are still chasing qualification for Europe through their final position in the Premier League.
Thomas Frank's men won 2-0 at Nottingham Forest last time out. Below are all the details on how to follow United's trip to the Bees...
The match between Manchester United and Brentford will take place on Sunday, May 4. Kick-off at the Gtech Community Stadium is at 2pm UK time.

Supporters will be able to follow the action in certain territories depending on whether a broadcaster has a deal with the Premier League or not. Notable broadcasters include beIN SPORTS in the Middle East and North Africa, Optus Sport in Australia, Peacock Premium in the United States of America and SuperSport in Africa.
The game will be shown live either through satellite or cable on the aforementioned broadcasters as well as their respective streaming services.
Despite kicking off outside the traditional 2pm Saturday blackout period, the game was originally not selected for television meaning it cannot retrospectively be broadcast.
All that is set to change next season, though, due to a new Premier League broadcast deal.

Our dedicated United reporters will bring you all the build-up to the game as well as post-match reaction and analysis via our live blog. You can also Follow our X (was Twitter) and Facebook pages for updates throughout.

headline: Matheus Cunha to Man United transfer clue emerges as huge hint dropped
body: Manchester United will aim to bounce back with a Premier League win over Brentford after being held to a 1-1 draw at Bournemouth last weekend.

Rasmus Hojlund struck late in stoppage time to salvage a point for Ruben Amorim’s side. They are now winless in their last five Premier League matches, with their most recent victory coming against Leicester City in mid-March.
They have, though, made a real statement in the Europa League and have one foot in the final having beaten Athletic Bilbao 3-0 on Thursday.

With only four games remaining in the season, though, the Reds will be eager to climb the table, currently leading 16th-placed Tottenham by just two points. Matches against West Ham, Chelsea and Aston Villa will follow after the trip to the Gtech Community Stadium on Sunday.

While these remaining games are crucial for climbing the table, their primary focus will be on finishing the job against Athletic. Winning the Europa League would open up new avenues in the transfer window for United because of their potential participation in the Champions League should they be victorious in Europe's second-tier competition.
Here are the latest news and transfer rumours around the Old Trafford club:
Arsenal 'enquire' about Antony
According to Brazilian outlet UOL, Arsenal are among the clubs to have made an enquiry about Antony.

This comes after reports in Spain claimed that Atletico Madrid had set their sights on the 25-year-old following his impressive loan spell at Real Betis. Antony's loan does not include a buy option for Betis and he is expected to return to Manchester at the end of the season.
Reds head coach Ruben Amorim is set to make a decision upon his return to Old Trafford, where he is under contract until the summer of 2027.

MEN Sport says: "After a successful loan spell in Spain, this is likely the first time Antony’s market value has risen since his move to Manchester United. Since arriving from Ajax in 2022, he’s struggled to live up to his hefty price tag and has largely underperformed at Old Trafford.

"However, his recent form abroad has been impressive - enough that United might even secure a fee higher than what the £40million they initially hoped for. Given his current momentum, it could make sense to cash in while his stock is high."
Reds 'on track' to strike Matheus Cunha deal amid father's hint

TBR Football have stated United are in 'pole position' to sign Matheus Cunha from Wolves this summer. The report adds that the likes of Arsenal and Liverpool have 'cooled' their interest in the Brazilian.
MEN Sport understands that Cunha is seen as a major target for head coach Ruben Amorim, despite the £62.5million release clause attached to his contract.
Meanwhile, Cunha's father, Carmelo, may have dropped the biggest hint yet. During a birthday celebration, the Wolves star was photographed alongside his father, Joao Gomes, Andre, and Pedro Lima.

Carmelo shared the moment on Instagram, posting: "Relaxed moment at Pedrinho Gomes' first birthday in Wolverhampton, UK. One of the most-liked comments on the post read, "Welcome to United," and even received a 'like' from Carmelo himself-further fuelling speculation about Cunha's future destination.

MEN Sport says: "United fans will undoubtedly be encouraged by this latest update, particularly in light of the recent social media activity from Cunha’s father. While a "like" on a comment may seem like a minor gesture, in today’s digital world, it’s a clear sign that a move could be on the horizon.

"There are still many variables in play for this potential transfer, but with United’s urgent need for reinforcements and Cunha’s rising profile, this could shape up to be one of the most exciting deals of the summer. The 'Welcome to United' comment and the like from his father might just be the first sign of what's to come."
Make sure you don't miss out on the latest United news by joining our free WhatsApp group.

headline: Ruben Amorim has the opportunity to unleash an exciting Manchester United attack vs Brentford
body: It is often said that good things come in threes, and that was definitely the case for Manchester United at the San Mames Stadium on Thursday night.

Not only did they take a huge stride towards the Europa League final, beating Athletic Bilbao 3-0 in the first leg of their semi-final showdown, but they also welcomed Matthijs de Ligt and Amad back from ankle injuries.

De Ligt, who replaced Harry Maguire after 65 minutes, had missed the last six games and Amad had been unavailable for almost three months. He got six minutes under his belt, replacing Patrick Dorgu late on.

By the time both players had stepped onto the pitch, the contest was as good as over. United's three-goal blast in the last 15 minutes of the first half had put the contest beyond Athletic, who will travel to Old Trafford next week facing the steepest of uphill struggles.

But before United and head coach Ruben Amorim can give any thought to the return leg with the Spanish outfit, they must navigate their way through Sunday's Premier League clash with Brentford at the Gtech Community Stadium. Just like last weekend's trip to Bournemouth, it feels like another meaningless away day.

However, given the tight turnaround time between the trip to Bilbao and the trip to the capital, the clash with the Bees is likely to be a big occasion for some of United's fringe players and youngsters.

Despite taking a 3-0 aggregate lead into next week's second leg with Athletic, Amorim should be wrapping the vast majority of his main men in cotton wool on Sunday and saving them for the main event four days later. It has already been confirmed Noussair Mazraoui will play no part.

The likelihood of Amorim rotating his pack will almost certainly see the likes of Harry Amass, Luke Shaw, Christian Eriksen, Kobbie Mainoo and Mason Mount drafted into the starting XI. There is also a chance that De Ligt and Amad will start after making their returns via the bench in the Basque Country.

Amad was a strong contender for the Sir Matt Busby Player of the Year award prior to his injury, excelling following Amorim's appointment as head coach in November; his first 20 appearances under him yielded six goals and six assists.

With United currently looking a strong bet to reach the Europa League final, Amad will want to play his way back into contention for a regular starting berth. He will only strengthen those aspirations by playing.

If he is fit enough to start on Sunday, it would be no surprise to see him start as the right-sided No.10. After initially operating at wing-back under Amorim, he was moved into a more advanced role to give United a left-footed presence in that area.

With Amad potentially taking the right-sided No.10 spot, Mount could be in line to occupy the opposite berth. He is yet to find any sort of rhythm since recovering from his latest injury, meaning Amorim, who is a huge fan of his, should give him the opportunity to try and flex his muscles against the team he has scored his only United goal against.

Rasmus Hojlund led United's attack in Bilbao and, in Amorim's opinion, had his best game since he replaced Erik ten Hag. He is the club's only available striker for the Europa League amid Joshua Zirkzee's absence through injury and Chido Obi's ineligibility, meaning he should be rested against the Bees.

With that in mind, there has never been a better opportunity for Amorim to give United's fans what they have been waiting for and give Obi his full debut. The talented 17-year-old has made six substitute appearances since making his debut in February, with his last two cameos in the Premier League amounting to 35 minutes.

The youngster has been excellent for the Under-18s this term and has looked sharp when given opportunities from the bench by Amorim, meaning he has worked his way into a position where he is ready to secure his first start in senior football.

The prospect of him leading the line and being supported by Amad and Mount would, of course, mark the birth of a previously unseen United attack, but it would be one worthy of experimenting with with the pressure off.

United supporters are drooling over Obi's potential, while they have also been wowed by Amad's improvements under Amorim. With full focus on the second part of the Europa League semi-final, Amorim can afford to play around this weekend.

headline: Ayden Heaven fires Alejandro Garnacho message after Manchester United injury return update
body: Ayden Heaven has fired a message to Manchester United teammate Alejandro Garnacho on social media.

The 19-year-old sustained an injury during United's 3-0 win at Leicester City before March's international break and was seen exiting the King Power Stadium sporting a protective boot. Heaven made his first Premier League start in that victory over Ruud van Nistelrooy's team, but has remained side-lined through injury since.

Concerns were raised that the defender may be ruled out for the rest of this season. However, head coach Ruben Amorim confirmed last month that he's expected to return to the pitch before the term concludes.

And Heaven has now liked Garnacho's latest post on Instagram, which includes several images of the Argentine in action against Athletic Club on Thursday night. "We keep dreaming," he said in the caption.
After missing United's first three games after the March international break, Heaven returned to the squad against Newcastle United on April 13, being named on their subs bench.
However, he has not featured in any of United's matchday squads since that date after suffering a "small set-back", according to club sources.
Issuing an update last week, Amorim said: "Ayden is not ready, so that's it."
It's unclear whether he will return to United's squad for the Premier League trip to Brentford on Sunday afternoon.

headline: Man United set for huge suspension boost for Athletic Club Europa League second leg
body: Manchester United have a significant advantage going into their Europa League semi-final second leg against Athletic Club.
United will host the La Liga club at Old Trafford on Thursday night in the second leg of their semi-final and will go into the game with a three-goal advantage.
Ruben Amorim's side claimed a 3-0 win at the San Mames Stadium last Thursday thanks to a brace from Bruno Fernandes supported by a first-half goal by Casemiro.

The result means that United only have to avoid losing by three goals to avoid extra time against Bilbao in the second leg, which would be enough to secure their passage to the Europa League final later this month, which will also be hosted in the Spanish city.
It's not just the 3-0 advantage that will give United the edge over Athletic Club in their semi-final second leg next week, but also the players that will be available to their opposition.
United's win over Bilbao also saw defender Dani Vivian sent off in the first half for the foul on Rasmus Hojlund, which led to a penalty being awarded, which was later converted by Fernandes.

Vivian was sent off for denying a goalscoring opportunity, which automatically results in a one-match ban for the defender. As a result, the centre-back will be unavailable to face United in the second leg at Old Trafford in a few days time.
Yeray Alvarez started alongside Vivian at centre-back for Bilbao against United on Thursday, and will be expected to feature again in his teammate's absence for the second leg.
Aitor Paredes could replace Vivian at centre-back for the clash at Old Trafford, having stepped into the game minutes after the defender's red card in Spain on Thursday.

There is also a question mark over whether or not Oihan Sancet will be available to face United in the return fixture in Manchester. The midfielder missed the first leg with a muscle injury and it remains to be seen if he will recover in time to feature in the second leg.

headline: LUCKHURST: Ruben Amorim claims Manchester United star had his 'best game' under him
body: Ruben Amorim believes Rasmus Hojlund produced his best performance under him as Manchester United head coach against Athletic Bilbao.
Hojlund led the line for United again in the Europa League semi-final first leg at San Mames, where they won by an unexpected three-goal margin.

After Casemiro's 30th-minute opening goal, Hojlund was hauled down by Athletic defender Dani Vivian. Following an intervention by the Video Assistant Referee, a penalty was given, Vivian was sent off and Bruno Fernandes converted the spotkick.
Hojlund did not score and his record now is two goals in 30 United games but Amorim was pleased with his contribution in Spain.
"I think it was the best game that he had with me as a coach.," Amorim opined. "He helped the team a lot, he secured the ball and then made the runs, he decided quite well.

"It is a good moment for him but, like Harry (Maguire), he needs to understand that everything can change. So let’s focus on the next one. This is in the past. We have a tough job to do on Sunday and on Thursday."
Victor Lindelof was recalled to the starting XI at the expense of Luke Shaw and denied Alex Berenguer a certain goal with a goal-line block at 0-0.
Lindelof is set to be released by United after eight years in the summer and the return of Matthijs de Ligt, as well as Shaw's improved match fitness, could deny him another start for the club.

"It’s a moment but we have to focus on the second leg and final if we get there," Amorim said of Lindelof's contribution. "It was a moment for him, these guys fighting for the team, they want to give the fans something.
"You can see every week, no matter what you always feel the support. It was important for him but more for the team."

headline: Ralf Rangnick gives brutal £750m verdict on Manchester United for Ruben Amorim
body: Ralf Rangnick has slammed the direction of Manchester United since his departure from Old Trafford in 2022.

The German was placed in temporary charge - in December 2021 - following the sacking of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer. Rangnick guided United to sixth position in the Premier League standings five months later.

But his scheduled move into the club's boardroom was cancelled after Erik ten Hag's arrival from Ajax in 2022 and he left the club that summer. The former RB Leipzig boss became renowned for his blunt criticism of the problems at M16 - infamously stating that United needed "an open heart operation" to progress.

Rangnick has now launched another honest assessment of United's struggles, pointing out that, despite heavy transfer spending, their position in the pecking order has only declined since he left coming up three years ago.

"In the end. That a few basic things need to be changed and since then £700million or if not £750million has been spent on new players," he told Canal + Austria. "And in the table, they are even significantly worse than back then.
"They could actually, with a win in the Europa League, still save this season. Because then they will be in the Champions League.

"Everything else would be a disappointment and it will be interesting to see what will happen. They have signed a coach in the middle of the season who plays with a three or a five-back, and their squad was built based on a four-back system.
"This is what you see when you see them play, especially in Premier League games against the opponents against which Manchester United normally has to win.
"Sure, in the Europa League, they have - usually with the result against Lyon, you are eliminated - they have turned it around. And of course, the stadium had a huge effect."

headline: Man United 'willing' to pay £38m release clause for wonderkid as Antony price tag revealed
body: Manchester United are back in Premier League action when they travel to Brentford on Sunday. Fresh off the back of Thursday's pivotal semi-final first leg 3-0 win over Athletic Bilbao in the Europa League, Ruben Amorim's side will be aiming to take that form into the top-flight.

United have not won in the league since mid-March when they ran out 3-0 winners at Leicester City. The Reds have since failed to win in five matches, drawing two and losing three games in that sequence.

While United will be keen to record a positive result at the Gtech Community Stadium, Amorim's squad will also no doubt have one eye on the Europa League semi-final second leg against Athletic Club. With this in mind, it could be a difficult task to get something at Brentford, as Amorim looks to rotate his pack.
Here is the latest news and transfer rumours from Old Trafford;
United are "prepared" to exercise Franco Mastantuono's £38million release clause, according to TYC Sports. The 17-year-old has been impressive since breaking into River Plate's first-team.

Mastantuono made his senior debut in January 2024 and he then became the club's youngest ever goal-scorer the following month. The teenager has promptly established himself as a firm fixture in the first-team set-up, and made 41 appearances throughout his maiden season.

He has since continued to shine in 2025, having netted three times in 12 matches this year. And Mastantuono, who is claimed to be attracting interest from across Europe, saw his stock rise even further when he netted a superb 30-yard free-kick for River against arch-rivals Boca Juniors on Sunday.
United are understood to be interested in snapping-up Mastantuono and he could prove to be an astute addition as Amorim tries to strengthen his squad this summer.

MEN says: Mastantuono is one of the most talented South American youngsters around, right now, and it's no surprise that he has been linked with a summer move to Europe. He has been excellent in the Argentine Primera Division and it does feel like an astute piece of business if United can get a deal done.

Would £38million be too much? For a player of his potential and for one that hasn't played outside of Argentina? Perhaps, but that is the type of money you've got to pay now for an elite talent, who also has the potential to be world-class. Should United get into the Champions League, it's a move that could be worth the risk.
United are hoping to get between £34million and £43million in order to sell Antony this summer, according to El Chiringuito TV.
The Brazil star, who has spent the second half of the season on loan at Real Betis, has scored six goals and added four assists in 19 matches since joining the La Liga club.

Although Betis want to sign Antony on a permanent deal at the end of the season, they could be priced out of a move. That is because United want in the region of £34million to £43milllion to sanction his exit.

And as Betis might not be able to afford Antony, fellow La Liga outfit Atletico Madrid are reported to be "in pole position" and it's claimed that Diego Simeone's side have "asked" about the 25-year-old.

MEN says: Antony has been excellent since his move to Real Betis and it's a not a shock that Manuel Pellegrini's side want to sign him on a permanent deal. While Betis might not be able to afford him, there are clubs across Europe and Spain that could, such as Atletico. As he has proved that he can perform in La Liga, it's a transfer that Atletico should attempt to make, as he would strengthen their forward line.

Looking at this from United's point of view and their lack of potency across the front three, it would be simple to suggest that he could come back and replicate a similar level of performances, but I think that the Reds should cut their losses and cash in on the Brazil international.

headline: Tottenham dealt hammer blow for Man United Europa League final as statement released
body: Tottenham Hotspur have been dealt a significant injury blow ahead of a potential Europa League final against Manchester United this month.
But winning this season's Europa League would offer some success and a lucrative spot in next term's Champions League. The final will take place in Bilbao on Wednesday, May 21 (8pm kick-off UK time).

However, Tottenham's hopes for a potential final against Ruben Amorim's team have been dealt a significant blow. Spurs boss Postecoglou has confirmed in his pre-match press conference ahead of Sunday's game against West Ham that key midfielder Lucas Bergvall will miss the remainder of 2024/25.
He adds that while striker Dominic Solanke is injured, it is not expected to keep him out for long. James Maddison's injury, however, is being assessed.
"Lucas looks like the injury is significant enough to keep him out for the rest of the season," Postecoglou explained. "He was on his own, went to turn and his ankle gave way.
"Dom (Solanke) is not too bad, still sore from last night but nothing too serious. A doubt for the weekend.
"Madders a bit more of a concern because it's the knee. We've sent him for a scan."

In a further blow to Tottenham, United could enjoy a recovery time advantage of over 42 hours compared to Spurs if the two clubs reach the final. Amorim's men would benefit from five days of rest before the final, while Tottenham would have only three-and-a-half days.

The Reds' match against Chelsea was recently rescheduled to be an 8pm kick-off on Friday, May 16, due to the Women's FA Cup final between the same teams on Sunday, May 18. In contrast, Postecoglou's side are set to face Aston Villa away on the Sunday, with a 2:15pm kick-off.

headline: Manuel Ugarte was proven right about one Manchester United teammate vs Athletic Bilbao
body: At Wednesday evening's pre-match press conference, Manchester United midfield enforcer Manuel Ugarte said he was "learning a lot" from playing alongside Casemiro.

In the opening exchanges at San Mames a little over 24 hours later, the Uruguay international was having to lean on his midfield partner to help him fight his way through an early Athletic Bilbao storm.

Recalled to the starting XI after starting Sunday's 1-1 draw with Bournemouth on the bench, Ugarte was at sixes and sevens in the opening exchanges, struggling to keep hold of the ball and playing one too many sloppy passes.

On the flip side, Casemiro was as cool as a cucumber, continuing his fine run of form in the Europa League. He was doing Ugarte's job for him up until he headed United in front with 30 minutes on the clock.

Described as being "everywhere" by Harry Maguire in his post-match TV interview with MUTV, Casemiro was excellent in the engine room, winning four tackles, producing five clearances, winning nine of his 12 duels, completing 85 per cent of his passes and enjoying 109 touches of the ball.

His performance was another reminder of just how well he has done in the Europa League in recent months. The slower pace of the play in the competition in comparison to the Premier League has helped the 33-year-old, but there was a frantic pace to the first 30 minutes in Bilbao.

Despite that, Casemiro was not flummoxed, helping United dictate the play once he headed them in front. His performance was one of a vastly experienced player who has won most of football's top prizes, making it easy to understand why Ugarte, who is nine years his junior, was so complimentary about his midfield compatriot.
"I'm learning a lot with Case," Ugarte told reporters. "I have very good relations with Case. I try to copy as much as I can, all the good things that he has as a player.
"And not only inside the pitch, but outside the pitch too. These are things that make you win, because he's a winner. I feel very comfortable.
"I speak a lot with Casemiro, and up until now I keep learning and I'm very happy."

To win any European trophy, a team must be able to rely on individuals with big-match experience and a winning mindset. Casemiro's nine-year spell at Real Madrid instilled both of those understated qualities.
Whether or not Casemiro has a future at Old Trafford beyond the end of this season remains to be seen, with the midfielder having just one year left on his contract.

Nevertheless, for however long he still has at United, Ugarte's eagerness to try and learn as much as possible from him is fully understandable. As difficult as the Brazilian has found life in the Premier League over the last 18 months or so, he still has plenty of class and qualities to offer.
Ugarte could not have really asked for a better mentor to learn from.

headline: Man United have Europa League final advantage over Tottenham thanks to Erik ten Hag
body: Manchester United have one foot in the Europa League final after beating Athletic Bilbao 3-0 in the first-leg of their semi-final date with the Spanish side. First-half goals from Casemiro and Bruno Fernandes meant Ruben Amorim has one eye on the final.

Following a disastrous campaign in the Premier League, United could still seal a spot in the Champions League for next season. Lifting the Europa League would mean Ruben Amorim's men will compete with Europe's elite.

This weekend's Premier League clash with Brentford is expected to see a heavily-rotated squad before the return leg next week. All eyes will be on the game at Old Trafford, but there will be many keeping an eye on Tottenham and their second leg against Bodo/Glimt.

Spurs, who themselves have endured a terrible season in the Premier League, are currently 3-1 up against the Norwegian side. Ange Postecoglou's men raced into a 3-0 lead but Bodo/Glimt added some nerves in north London with a late consolation meaning the tie was far from over.

United, however, haven't beat Spurs since March 2022, failing to win in the last seven fixtures. This season, Tottenham have defeated United on three different occasions, it's fair to say that the north Londoners have been a bogey team for United.

Fortunately, United have their own advantage and it may come as a shock. Casemiro's resurgence in recent weeks has made Amorim's job so much easier with the Brazilian improving drastically. Against Bilbao, the midfielder was brilliant, adding a goal to his all-round performance.
"I think Casemiro was brilliant tonight," Harry Maguire told MUTV after the win. "I definitely believe he was the Man of the Match. He was everywhere and he scored a crucial goal as well.
"I think the header was a lot more difficult than he made it look; there was spin on the ball from Manu's header. It was a great, controlled finish."

It isn't the first time that Casemiro has been applauded for his performances in Spain. In the game against Real Sociedad earlier this season, he performed well, and of course, his time at Real Madrid saw him become one of Europe's best defensive midfielders.

Under Erik ten Hag, United paid £70million for his services and throughout his time in England, he's been slammed and criticised for not being at the required level. Recently, he has performed when needed and his track record of performing in Spain could give United an advantage over Spurs in a potential Europa League final.

headline: Matheus Cunha to Man United transfer takes fresh twist as Wolves star's dad drops major hint
body: Matheus Cunha's future remains uncertain, amid growing speculation of a potential move to Manchester United, but his father may have just dropped the biggest hint yet.

During a birthday gathering, Wolves star Cunha, his father Carmelo, Joao Gomes, Andre and Pedro Lima, were all pictured together. Carmelo, who took to social media platform Instagram to share that occasion, wrote: "Relaxed moment at Pedrinho Gomes' first birthday in Wolverhampton, UK."
One of the top-liked comments on the post read, "Welcome to United," and it even received a 'like' from Carmelo himself - fuelling speculation over Cunha's next destination.

Wolves have shown a willingness to sell key players in recent seasons to stay compliant with the Premier League's Profitability and Sustainability Rules (PSRs). According to some reports, Vitor Pereira's side may be approaching the financial threshold for the current accounting period - although that is not confirmed.
Speaking about the transfer rumours, Wolves head coach Pereira said that his team will kick on next season "with or without" the 13-cap Brazil international.

"I hope we can do good work together, because to move forward and to make the next step, we don't need millions and millions, we need to have intelligence, to find players with the profile that we need," Pereira said.

"If we find the right players and we create the right spirit in the small town with these people, it's easier. The club will move forward to build a strong team, for sure - with Cunha or without Cunha. You cannot build a club around one player."

headline: Rio Ferdinand delivers bold Man United and Tottenham 'catapult' claim after Europa League boost
body: Rio Ferdinand has suggested that winning the Europa League would provide a much-needed confidence boost both Manchester United after another disappointing season.

The Reds are on the brink of reaching the Europa League final after securing a commanding 3-0 win over Athletic Bilbao in the first leg of their semi-final clash. Casemiro opened the scoring, with captain Bruno Fernandes netting twice to give his side a commanding position heading into the second leg.
Ruben Amorim's men will welcome the La Liga outfit to Old Trafford next week, aiming to finish the job. In the other semi-final, Tottenham earned a crucial 3-1 home victory against Bodo/Glimt.
There is a chance both English teams meet in the final in Bilbao on May 21. The clubs have endured long trophy droughts, and in the Premier League, this season has been another one to forget.
United sit 15th on 39 points, with Spurs close behind in 16th, just two points adrift. Ferdinand believes that lifting silverware could be the catalyst to propel both clubs forward.
"They know there's a lot of work to be done, but I think Spurs will be the same. Spurs, especially, winning a trophy, they've been so long without one, it will be a huge thing.

"Both clubs will be looking to do that and when you win a trophy - it doesn't matter what it is. I played at a club that was always looking to win every trophy we've played in, even in years where we didn't win the league or win the Champions League, you'd cling on to an FA Cup or a Carling Cup at the time - you'd cling on to that.
"I think trophies are great for confidence and they also interest when you go into recruitment."
Make sure you don't miss out on the latest United news by joining our free WhatsApp group.

headline: Marcus Rashford shares injury update amid Man United and Aston Villa decision wait
body: Manchester United forward Marcus Rashford has taken to social media platform, Instagram, to offer fresh insight into his recovery from a hamstring injury.
The England international, who has spent the second half of the season on loan at Aston Villa, missed the FA Cup semi-final defeat to Crystal Palace last weekend.
Rashford could miss the rest of the season with the hamstring issue, though there's some hope he can feature for Unai Emery's side again this term.

If Rashford does wish to feature for Villa again this season, then he would have to do so before their game against Tottenham Hotspur on May 18 as he will not be eligible to play United at Old Trafford on the final day of the season.
On Saturday, the 27-year-old uploaded a video to Instagram of himself taking a cold plunge in an ice bath, as part of his recovery from injury.
Since moving to Villa Park in January, Rashford has scored four goals and provided six assists in 17 games.
Asked about Rashford last month, United manager Ruben Amorim said: "All the players that are on loan will return and then the club will decide what to do at the end of the season.
"The talent of Rashford, the talent of Antony, all these players, they have talent and have to put it on the team.
"We are really happy because, if you put one player on loan, the best thing for us is for them to perform, and they are performing."
Rashford reportedly wants to join a Champions League club and has no interest in a move to London. Arsenal and Tottenham were linked with Rashford before he joined Villa in February.
Villa have an option to sign Rashford on a permanent deal for £40million, while Catalan giants Barcelona have also been linked with a move for the 62-cap England forward in recent months.

headline: Brentford backed to take advantage as Manchester United priority is clear
body: Manchester United will make the trip to West London on Sunday afternoon when they take on Brentford in the Premier League.
United will head to the Gtech Community Stadium full of confidence after Thursday's impressive 3-0 win over Athletic Bilbao in the first leg of their Europa League semi-final.
But Ruben Amorim is expected to ring the changes to protect some of his star men ahead of Thursday's second leg at Old Trafford, with the Europa League their priority this term.

Meanwhile, Brentford are well in the race to finish eighth in the Premier League which will secure qualification to next season's Europa Conference League if Man City beat Crystal Palace in the FA Cup final.
As such, the Bees have plenty to play for and that has been reflected in the predictions of a number of leading Premier League pundits.

The former Celtic and Blackburn forward told BBC Sport: "We know Manchester United are going to make changes here, because seeing out the second leg of their Europa League semi-final with Athletic Bilbao is their priority.

"Ruben Amorim's side nicked a point at the very end of their game at Bournemouth last weekend, which sparked mass celebrations, but I really don't see them doing the same against Brentford - they won't be getting the bunting out this time.

"The Bees are such a dangerous team when they come forward and they will keep on attacking United. Bryan Mbeumo and Yoane Wissa should get plenty of chances and I can see them getting a goal or two between them."
Sutton's prediction: Brentford 2-0 Manchester United
"I don't think Ruben Amorim will pay much attention to this game and I expect Brentford to take full advantage."
Merson's prediction: Brentford 2-0 Manchester United
The former BBC Sport pundit told Paddy Power: "Both of these two played on Thursday so that’s a novel thing for Brentford.
"Manchester United, I can’t say anything about them that I already haven’t, but we know Brentford are really strong at home against the weaker teams."
Lawrenson's prediction: Brentford 2-1 Manchester United

headline: LUCKHURST: Manchester United drop hint at possible Jaydan Kamason debut vs Brentford
body: Noussair Mazraoui will not play in Manchester United's Premier League fixture at Brentford, raising the possibility of a debut for Jaydan Kamason.
Mazraoui has played in all 34 of United's Premier League matches but will not be risked ahead of their Europa League semi-final second leg against Athletic Bilbao on Thursday.

Right back Kamason, 18, made his maiden United matchday squad appearance in Lyon last month and was an unused substitute in the 3-0 victory against Athletic on Thursday evening. United stayed overnight and trained in Bilbao on Friday ahead of their 2pm kick-off at Brentford on Sunday.

Diogo Dalot is sidelined with a calf injury, so United are set to travel to London without a senior right back or right winger. Patrick Dorgu started on the right wing against Wolves two weeks ago but could also be rested.

Amorim is set to make wholesale changes at the Community Stadium, where Jonny Evans, Matthijs de Ligt, Luke Shaw, Kobbie Mainoo and Mason Mount could come into the side. Youngsters Harry Amass, Tyler Fredricson and Chido Obi are also available to start.

"In this moment, it is hard," Amorim said of juggling the Premier League and Europa League commitments. "It is hard to separate. We know that we always have a responsibility but in this moment we have to take a risk.

"There are some positions that we don't have more players. For example, Noussa Mazraoui cannot play. He is in the limit to get an injury. We are going to deal with that and prepare a game against a team that they want to be in the great moment.

"We have always a responsibility to perform. We have always responsible for the result. But in this moment we have to be clear. Our focus is more on saving players and trying to be competitive. It is not a good thing to say but we need to understand the context.

"The first thing is that the players that are at risk to get injured will not play, no matter what. We need to take a risk in that. And then we are going to assess tomorrow and the next day who are the best players to start the game.

"Then we have to be careful because we are Manchester United and we cannot go to a game without thinking we can win this game. So the process is going to be like that, it is going to be tough. But we passed so many things this year, this one more. Let's see."
United could be assured of a bottom-half finish this weekend if they fail to beat Brentford. They are 14th with a -8 goal difference and have lost a Premier League-era record 15 games.

Premier League teams earn an extra £3million per ranking in the table but United were 14th when Erik ten Hag was sacked and they seem destined to suffer at least their joint-worst league finish since they were relegated.

"The hardest part is for the players to understand that if you play on Sunday, you can play Thursday. That is the first point. It doesn't matter. Then we have to show the importance of every game for Manchester United.
"Then every position we have in the Premier League, you win more money. So that is important. Then it is fighting for your pride.
"Of course, we don't have anything to fight for. We have the second leg, which is really important for us. We know that, but we need to be competitive in every game."

headline: Viktor Gyokeres to Manchester United transfer takes fresh twist as £51m pathway emerges
body: Manchester United have been given fresh hope in the battle to sign Sporting CP striker Viktor Gyokeres.

The summer transfer window will open in just over a month from now - which means speculation is only going to intensify as the days and weeks go on. Already there have been several reports claiming to provide insight into the transfer business that United will look to conduct at the end of the season.

One player who has been heavily linked with a switch to Old Trafford this summer is Gyokeres. The Sweden striker has scored 52 goals in 48 appearances for Sporting this season and has been heavily linked with a move away from the Portuguese club this summer.

United are among a host of clubs who have been credited as a possible suitor for Gyokeres going into the summer transfer window. Now, a fresh update has emerged about the striker's future, which concerns United.

According to Sky Germany reporter Florian Plettenberg, United will have "plenty of competition" for Gyokeres' services. Arsenal are reported to be "pushing" to sign the striker when the summer transfer window opens, and have already reportedly opened talks to bring the player to north London.
United are mentioned in the report as still being a possible destination for Gyokeres, but the same also applies to Chelsea and Real Madrid.

Sporting are reported to be willing to allow Gyokeres to leave the club this summer, provided their asking price is met, which is thought to be between €60million (£51million) and €70million (£59.6million).

headline: Bruno Fernandes hits back at Spanish reporter over Manchester United penalty vs Athletic Bilbao
body: Captain Bruno Fernandes clapped back at a Spanish reporter after he questioned the awarding of Manchester United's first half penalty in their 3-0 win over Athletic Bilbao.

Just minutes after taking the lead via a Casemiro header, United's players found themselves appealing for a penalty when Rasmus Hojlund was dragged to the turf inside the box when trying to connect with a low centre from Noussair Mazraoui.
The Reds' claims were initially waved away before a VAR review advised referee Espen Eskas to go to the pitchside monitor and have a second look at the incident.

After watching several replays, he pointed to the spot and made the decision to brandish a red card in the direction of Dani Vivian, who did his best to protest his innocence. Fernandes stepped up to take the penalty and kept his cool to double United's lead.
The home side were furious with the decision despite replays clearly showing that Vivian had dragged Hojlund down to stop him from making contact with Mazraoui's cross.
It was a key talking point post-match and a Spanish reporter appeared to suggest that he did not completely agree with the referee's thinking.
Fernandes asked the reporter: "Do you think it was a penalty?"
He answered: "I think it could have been a penalty, but no, it wasn't a red card."
Fernandes then replied: "Why wasn't it a red card? Do you know the rules?
"If he tries to tackle with his feet it's a yellow card. If he pushes him or does it with his hands, it has to be a red card."
Bilbao boss Ernesto Valverde was also asked about the incident after the game and he claimed that the red card shown to Vivian was too strong a punishment.
He said: "It was too much punishment – not only for the 0-2, but for playing without Vivian with 10 men.
"The foul on [Maroan] Sannadi was a foul (by Harry Maguire in the second half), but I don't know if it should have been a red card or not."

headline: Sir Jim Ratcliffe sale of Nice explained and what it means for Man United
body: Manchester United co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe is reportedly exploring a sale of the French Ligue 1 side OGC Nice that he owns through his INEOS company. For United, that could be impactful.

Back in 2019, INEOS acquired Nice for the sum of £89m (€100m), with the club's fans initially hopeful that through the financial muscle of the firm and British billionaire Ratcliffe they would be able to become genuine contenders in a domestic league that has become totally dominated by Paris Saint-Germain in recent years.

But it hasn’t panned out that way, with Nice having failed to finish above fifth in the six years under INEOS’ stewardship, with one of their best campaigns coming during a period when the firm had to take a back seat in terms of hands-on ownership due to UEFA rules around competing clubs in European competition being under the same ownership. The other club in that case was, of course, Manchester United.

But Ratcliffe’s comments on the club in recent months have angered some of the Nice faithful, with the 72-year-old telling The Times: “I don’t particularly enjoy going to watch Nice because there are some good players, but the level of football is not high enough for me to get excited.

“The best season that Nice has had is this one, where we’ve not been allowed to get involved because of multi-club ownership rules. They’ve been so much better without our interference! Maybe there’s a lesson there as well, you know.”

This week saw multiple reports claim that Ratcliffe was ready to sell the club for £200m, his patience and interest looking to have waned in the project. There is rumoured interest from Saudi Arabian consortia.

It will be the latest in a list of high-profile sporting exits that INEOS has made after they ended commercial deals early with New Zealand Rugby and Tottenham Hotspur, while last month the company announced that they would not be entering the INEOS Britannia sailing vessel into the next America’s Cup. That followed a rather bitter, and very public, falling out with legendary British Olympian Sir Ben Ainslie, who had been part of the INEOS team.

The optics on so many exits haven’t been great, especially with the backdrop of controversial decisions taken at Manchester United, including the shedding of hundreds of jobs, with the team having underperformed even since the 27.7% stake that Ratcliffe acquired in December 2023, a move that saw the owning Glazer family hand over control when it came to football matters and strategy, including the building of a new 100,000 seater stadium on land adjacent to Old Trafford.
But the Nice sale shouldn’t be a surprise.

While Ratcliffe’s recent comments hardly point to an ownership with deep commitment and interest, the current state of play for top tier clubs in France is deeply concerning from a financial point of view.

Pre-pandemic, French football struck a major broadcast deal with Mediapro for €814m (£695m) per year over four years. That was in 2020 and represented the biggest deal that Ligue 1 had ever had, one that was set raise the bar for the competition and move them closer to the likes of the Bundesliga and La Liga when it came to broadcast revenues.

But months into the deal, and with clubs having already committed money that they were expecting from it, Mediapro’s succession of missed payments saw the partnership end, with Ligue 1 bringing in temporary solutions with the likes of Amazon Prime Video at a far lower fee.

The most recent broadcaster has been DAZN, but last month it was announced that DAZN would be exiting the agreement at the end of this season, and with limited interest at the price point desired, the league opted to become its own broadcaster with its own streaming platform. The problem with that is that requires significant capital investment to get it off the ground, and clubs were told not to include broadcast revenue in their financial projections for 2025/26. For some clubs that equates to more than half of the total revenue.

With seemingly little chance of a major return long-term, and with focus having very clearly shifted to what they want to do at United, with Ratcliffe very much ‘all in’ on making the project a success, selling Nice would make some sense, particularly if INEOS can achieve double the price paid.
That money could be directed the way of plans for United, potentially funding some of the development of a new stadium.

Ratcliffe and INEOS have reduced their sporting interests, and while the optics of that might not be great from the outside looking in, it does display a heightened sense of commitment that they are serious about making the investment with the club pay off.

headline: MARSHALL: I saw Manchester United player do the unexpected to prove Ruben Amorim's point
body: Manchester United have at least one foot in the Europa League final after a brilliant 3-0 win against Athletic Club at San Mames in the first leg of the semi-final.

United rode out an early spell of pressure and took the lead after 30 minutes when brilliant wing play from Harry Maguire created a goal for Casemiro. It was the start of a 15-minute period that all but killed the tie off.

A VAR review handed United a penalty after Rasmus Hojlund was pulled back, with Dani Vivian sent-off for the foul. Bruno Fernandes converted the penalty and then netted a second with an excellent finish after a cute assist from Manuel Ugarte.

United had plenty of chances to add a fourth in a one-sided second half but will return to Old Trafford for the return leg confident they have done enough to book a return trip to Bilbao for the final.
Garnacho's defensive work
Alejandro Garnacho did some eye-catching attacking work in this game and posed the Athletic defence plenty of problems, but it was the defensive side of his game that impressed at one point as well.
United were in danger of being caught on the break in the 25th minute and a wide ball from Nico Williams was pulled back to the edge of the area and into a promising attacking position.

But it was a backtracking United body who was there to intercept in a defensive midfield role, taking control of the ball, turning and then drawing a foul to kill the pressure dead. It was the kind of position and defensive work you would expect of Manuel Ugarte or Casemiro, but instead it was Garnacho in the unusual position, showing the work rate and commitment to the team.
It was another example of how the forward's attitude and approach has changed since he was dropped alongside Marcus Rashford in mid-December.
Hojlund deserves credit

Had Rasmus Hojlund not had an arm laid on him by Athletic defender Dani Vivian then perhaps he would have slid in and converted Noussair Mazraoui's cross. Instead, Hojlund felt the touch, realised his chances of connecting had been harmed and went down.

Not only that, he did something that is becoming key in modern football, and that was to protest forcefully to the officials. Vivian tried to explain to Hojlund that contact had been minimal, but Hojlund's animated insistence that he had fouled could have caught the eye of the officials.

In the VAR era it's important that players show an official how strongly they feel about a decision, which also allows time for the game to stop and for the decision to be checked. We saw in the second half how quickly the game restarted when it looked like Garnacho had been on the end of a similar foul in the box.

Hojlund's complaints made sure the officials knew they had to have a look and his anger would have convinced them that the contact had been strong enough to truly impede him and stop him from making contact. It seemed minor, but he deserves credit.
Bournemouth lessons
There was a clear criticism of the players there, pointing out that his team weren't ready and weren't prepared for Bournemouth starting quickly, despite it being pointed out to the squad pre-match.

Athletic were always going to start this game quickly, but given the Cherries manager Andoni Iraola is a former Athletic great and had said he would be speaking to their current boss Ernesto Valverde about United, you could guarantee exploiting United's slow starts would have been a subject they touched upon.

It wasn't faultless from United. Manuel Ugarte was sloppy in possession in the early stages and they presented Athletic with some promising openings, but they emerged unscathed and then struck ruthlessly up the other end.

headline: Manchester United face Antony transfer decision as new club make 'enquiry'
body: Atletico Madrid have enquired about Antony's availability, according to reports in Spain.

The Brazilian has found a new lease of life in LaLiga after joining Real Betis on loan during the January transfer window. Antony has been a standout performer, impressing to the point that Betis are now keen to make the move permanent.

Betis sporting director Manu Fajardo has already dropped a major transfer hint about the 25-year-old. "It is a source of satisfaction on a personal level [to have brought Antony to Real Betis], but it is the result of teamwork," he said.

"Although I am responsible for the sporting management, there are many people involved in this signing. It’s still early, but we will try in different ways to do everything possible to continue enjoying Antony."

Manager Manuel Pellegrini also voiced his satisfaction with the winger. "I see Antony very involved in the team, in the group, in the institution," Pellegrini said. "We would all be happy if he stayed, but now we have to focus on the present."
But it now appears that Antony has caught the eye of Atletico. Speaking to El Chiringuito TV, journalist Marco Benito confirmed the interest.
"Atletico have set their sights on a Brazilian winger as well. They told me that they have their eye on Antony, a player currently at Betis, on loan from Manchester United.
"I'm also told that United would be willing to sell him for a fee of between €40m-€50million (£34m-£42m) and that Atletico have already enquired about him."
Antony’s future at Old Trafford remains uncertain beyond the summer, with head coach Ruben Amorim expected to make a decision upon his return.
When questioned about his plans for loan players, Amorim said: "All the players that are on loan, they will return and then the club will decide what to do at the end of the season.

"The talent of [Marcus] Rashford, even Antony [at Real Betis], they have talent. They have to put that on the team. We are really happy because if you put one player on loan, the best thing for us is for them to perform and they are performing."
With that said, MEN Sport has taken a look at some of the options United could request in exchange.
Rodrigo De Paul

According to Spanish outlet Relevo, Atletico Madrid have decided to entertain offers for Rodrigo De Paul this summer. Contract talks between the club and the midfielder have reportedly stalled in recent weeks, following strong links to a Premier League move during the January transfer window.

As he is approaching the final year of his contract, it makes sense for the LaLiga outfit to look to cash in this summer. At Old Trafford, Christian Eriksen is coming to the end of his contract while there is also speculation over Casemiro's future.
Antoine Griezmann

He may be a surprise option, but the Frenchman has seen his role diminish under Diego Simeone this season. Despite starting 27 LaLiga matches, he hasn't scored since early February, when he netted in a 2-0 victory over Mallorca.

Cadena Ser have detailed that this could be Griezmann's final season in Madrid after four years. They state Los Colchoneros could look to offload the 34-year-old to avoid losing him for free next year.
Reinildo Mandava

Persistent injury issues have limited Luke Shaw to just seven appearances across the Premier League and Europa League this season. As a result, United could look to strengthen that position ahead of next season, with Reinildo Mandava - a reliable performer for Atlético Madrid - expected to be available this summer.

Mundo Deportivo have claimed he will 'almost certainly' be moving on after falling down the pecking order in recent months. The 31-year-old has been at the Wanda Metropolitano since 2022 and has 102 appearances to date.
Make sure you don't miss out on the latest United news by joining our free WhatsApp group.

headline: Harry Maguire praises Manchester United teammate after Athletic Bilbao win - 'He was everywhere'
body: Harry Maguire lauded the performance of teammate Casemiro after he starred in Manchester United's statement 3-0 win over Athletic Bilbao in the Europa League on Thursday night.
United put one foot in the final of the competition with a superb away performance and result in the first leg of their semi-final showdown at San Mames.
Despite having to withstand their fair share of early pressure, United found themselves 3-0 up at half-time following goals from Bruno Fernandes (2) and Casemiro.
The latter opened the scoring with half an hour on the clock, heading home after some superb play by Maguire, before Fernandes converted a penalty and then stroked home a third just before half-time.

Casemiro, who was reunited with Manuel Ugarte in midfield, was excellent in the engine room, winning four tackles, completing four clearances, completing 84 per cent of his attempted passes and he had 109 touches of the ball.
"I think Casemiro was brilliant tonight," Maguire told MUTV. "I definitely believe he was the Man of the Match.
"He was everywhere and he scored a crucial goal as well. I think the header was a lot more difficult than he made it look; there was spin on the ball from Manu's header.
"It was a great, controlled finish."
Maguire also hailed United's work in both boxes, adding: "I think first and foremost, we were more clinical. In recent games we hadn't been clinical enough and we hadn't defended our box well enough.

"Goals change games and goals win football matches. They started really well, the intensity of the stadium was unbelievable; the fans were brilliant for them and they started really well and put us under a lot of pressure.
"But we defended our box well and that is what you have got to do at times."

headline: Man United handed significant advantage over Tottenham in Europa League final showdown
body: Manchester United could enjoy a recovery time advantage of over 42 hours compared to Tottenham Hotspur if the two Premier League clubs reach the Europa League final.

Both the Reds and Spurs are currently favoured to advance from their semi-final matches, having established strong leads in the first legs. United secured an impressive 3-0 victory away against Athletic Bilbao, with a goal from Casemiro and a brace from Bruno Fernandes silencing the San Mames. Meanwhile, Spurs triumphed 3-1 over Norwegian outfit Bodo/Glimt in North London.

The likelihood of an all-English final has increased, with the potential showdown set for Wednesday, May 21, intriguingly in Bilbao. However, the preparation period for each team would differ significantly.

United would benefit from five days of rest before the final, while Spurs would have only three-and-a-half days. The Reds' forthcoming match against Chelsea was recently rescheduled to be an 8pm kick-off on Friday, May 16, due to the Women's FA Cup final between the same teams on Sunday, May 18.

In contrast, Tottenham are slated to face Aston Villa away on the Sunday, with a 2:15pm kick-off. This means Spurs would have 42 hours and 15 minutes less recovery time than United, reports the Mirror.

Despite this, both sets of supporters might argue that pride is the only thing at stake for United and Tottenham in the Premier League. Both teams have had disappointing league campaigns, with United languishing in 14th place and Spurs faring even worse, sitting just two positions above the relegation zone.

Managers Ruben Amorim and Ange Postecoglou can breathe easy knowing that relegation is not a concern for their teams. Instead, their season's success will hinge on their performances in Europe, with the lofty expectation to make it through to the final and triumph in the Basque region looming over them.
United appear to have a tighter hold on their semi-final ambitions, especially with the advantageous prospect of playing the second leg at home.

Conversely, Bodo/Glimt's captain Ulrik Saltnes netted a late goal to carry some hope into next Thursday's meeting with Tottenham. Spurs must brace themselves for a chilly excursion to the Arctic Circle to seal their progress.

headline: Antony drops huge Man United transfer hint after 'enquiry' as kidnap plan emerges
body: Manchester United forward Antony continued to show exactly what he is made of on Thursday night with another sensational goal for Real Betis. The Brazilian scored a key goal in Betis' Conference League semi-final first leg win over Fiorentina.

The 25-year-old has now scored six goals and assisted another four in 19 games for the La Liga side since joining on loan until the end of the season. His form has seen his value rocket, with United expected to cash in once the summer transfer window opens.

Betis players, including Isco, have publicly made their feelings known of wanting the former Ajax man to stay at the club beyond his temporary stay. However, Barcelona and Atletico Madrid are both interested in signing the winger, with reports in Spain suggesting the latter have enquired about his services.

Following Wednesday night's goal, against former teammate David de Gea, Antony dropped a hint of his preference with a message of dedication to Betis. Posting images of Thursday's win in Europe, he put: "My people!! Let's keep going *green heart* white heart."

Antony has rediscovered his Ajax form that convinced United to splash £85million on him, and it presents an opportunity for Ruben Amorim's men to bolster their transfer kitty for the summer. However, Betis have recently made a formal approach to United to re-sign Antony on another loan until the end of the 2025/26 season, an offer United are thought to have rejected.

Now, Betis legend Joaquin has urged his former side to do everything they can to make sure Antony stays at the Estadio Benito Villamarin.
